meanings.definition: To cut off the top and branches of (a tree) to promote growth of a dense head of foliage.
meanings.sent1: The gardener was pollarding the tree to make it grow thicker leaves.
meanings.sent2: In spring, it is common to see people pollarding trees to encourage new growth.
meanings.sent3: The tree felt like a new haircut after the pollarding, with its branches neatly trimmed.
meanings.sent4: Pollarding the tree was like giving it a fresh start, ready to flourish with renewed energy.
meanings.sent5: The act of pollarding transformed the tree into a lush canopy of greenery.

meanings.sent1: Pollarding is an ancient method of tree maintenance used for centuries.
meanings.sent2: The park's beauty was enhanced by the skilled pollarding of its trees.
meanings.sent3: The squirrels found joy in the art of pollarding, creating new playgrounds in the branches.
meanings.sent4: In the world of trees, pollarding is like a stylish haircut that keeps them looking neat.
meanings.sent5: The art of pollarding turned the trees into sculpted works of nature.
